title: 114_hr776
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stark Administrative Simplification Act of 2015" and includes alternative sanctions for technical noncompliance with Stark rule under Medicare. Section 1877(g) of the Social Security Act is amended to include alternative sanctions for technical noncompliance with compensation arrangements under Medicare. The Social Security Act now includes alternative sanctions for technical noncompliance with Medicare compensation arrangements. Violations may result in a civil monetary penalty not exceeding $5,000 if disclosed within one year of noncompliance, or $10,000 if disclosed after one year. The Social Security Act allows for alternative sanctions for technical noncompliance with Medicare compensation arrangements. Violations may result in a civil monetary penalty of $10,000 for voluntary disclosures made after the initial date of noncompliance. The Secretary may reject a voluntary disclosure within 90 days if it doesn't meet requirements. If not rejected within 90 days, the disclosure is deemed accepted. The Secretary may reject a voluntary disclosure within 90 days if it doesn't meet requirements, but if not rejected within that time frame, the disclosure is deemed accepted. The disclosure submitted to the Secretary by a party to such arrangement must include identification of all parties involved, description of compensation paid, dates of noncompliance, and a certification of technical noncompliance. The noncompliant technical noncompliance must be cured or terminated, and the contract must be valid under State law and fair market value. Remuneration should not be determined in a way that takes into account noncompliance. Payment for civil monetary penalty under subparagraph (A) must be made in full. Technical noncompliance is defined as an arrangement violating subsection (a)(1) due to lack of a written or signed agreement. The Secretary shall apply this paragraph to noncompliant compensation arrangements disclosed before enactment, without final settlement. An Inspector's report is due within 24 months of enactment. The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the paragraph, including the number of disclosures, sanctions imposed, types of violations, and other relevant information.
